channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Canada Live Updates: Automakers Are Hobbled by Blockades at U.S.-Canada Border
item.description: Some of the world’s biggest car companies are shutting down or reducing production lines because of closures at the U.S.-Canada border, raising alarm in Canada about the effects on its economy.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Protestors opposing vaccine mandates blocking the roadway at the Ambassador Bridge border crossing, in Windsor, Ontario, on Wednesday.

item.title: With Buildup on Land and Sea, Russia Closes in on Ukraine
item.description: Military drills in Belarus, deployments in western Russia and Crimea, and planned naval exercises in the Black Sea gave an ominous undertone to a continuing diplomatic scramble.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops at front line position in Donetsk, Ukraine.

item.title: Armed Nationalists in Ukraine Pose a Threat Not Just to Russia
item.description: Kyiv is encouraging the arming of nationalist paramilitary groups to thwart a Russian invasion. But they could also destabilize the government if it agrees to a peace deal they reject.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuri Hudymenko, head of the Democratic Ax party, in the group’s offices on Thursday in Kyiv.

item.title: Upheaval in Northern Ireland, With Brexit at Its Center
item.description: A dispute over trading checks has left the main pro-British party in disarray, creating the potential for a momentous political shift.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pro-British mural in Belfast. Some unionists say Brexit arrangements have driven a wedge between Northern Ireland and mainland Britain.

item.title: In India, a Bellwether for Narendra Modi as Voters Head to Polls
item.description: While many voters say they are concerned about the economy, the prime minister’s party has placed a focus on religion, with often polarizing effects.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Voting began on Thursday in the state of Uttar Pradesh in northern India.

item.title: What to Know of the Canada Trucker Protests
item.description: Once narrowly focused on a vaccine mandate for drivers entering Canada from the U.S., the protests have ballooned into a sprawling campaign against various grievances.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: Hundreds of truck drivers and their supporters blocked the streets of downtown Ottawa on Thursday, part of a dayslong protest against public health measures.

item.title: Ottawa Protesters Turn a Quiet Capital Upside Down
item.description: The Ottawa protesters are giddy with their sense of collective purpose. But local residents see the demonstration as an unruly, disrespectful and even dangerous occupation.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Trucks blocking the streets of downtown Ottawa as part of a protest against Covid-19 mandates in Canada on Wednesday.

item.title: Libya Slides Deeper Into Chaos as Parliament Picks New Government
item.description: The current prime minister, Abdul Hamid Dbeiba, rejected Parliament’s decision, raising concerns that the oil-rich African nation was returning to a divide with two rival governments.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Mohammed Abdusamee

item.title: Prince Charles Again Tests Positive, Raising Concern About Risk to Queen
item.description: The heir to the British throne, 73, now in isolation, is infected for a second time; he first tested positive in March 2020 and had mild symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Charles this month. He is self-isolating after testing positive for the coronavirus.

item.title: Life Under the Specter of War: Images From Ukraine
item.description: With Russian forces menacing from three sides, Ukrainians are stoically keeping to their daily routines, but reminders of the looming threat are getting hard to avoid.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Hoffman, Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Heavy fighting has destroyed beach homes in Shyrokyne, Ukraine, on the Sea of Azov.

item.title: Tonga Is Receiving 'Contactless' Aid. There are Pros and Cons.
item.description: Covid-era travel restrictions have mostly prevented expatriate aid workers from flying into Pacific island nations after natural disasters. The results are mixed.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: David Cox/Australian Defence Force/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An Australian Army helicopter flying over Atata Island, Tonga, in February.

item.title: Americans Appeal Life Sentence for Killing an Italian Officer
item.description: Lawyers for Finnegan Elder and Gabriel Natale Hjorth, who received Italy’s toughest punishment for a 2019 fatal stabbing, hope to prove that their clients did not deserve such long terms.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Gabriel Natale Hjorth, left, and Finnegan Elder behind bars at their trial in Rome last year. Their case drew international headlines.

item.title: England Urges Farmers to Make Peace With Hikers
item.description: In a country where public access to parts of the countryside is written into law, the government gave landowners some advice. But farmers say they are not the problem.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Walking along a public footpath and through fields in Sevenoaks, England, in 2020.

item.title: Latvia Parliament Approves Holocaust Reimbursement for Jewish Community
item.description: “This law cannot bring back a destroyed community or a destroyed synagogue,” said a chairman of a group backing the effort. “But what it can do is recognize what happened.”
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola

item.title: Violence Erupts at Syrian Camp for ISIS Families, Leaving a Child Dead
item.description: Security forces say they opened fire this week after they were attacked by women and children at Al Hol camp in northeastern Syria, which holds about 60,000 family members of former ISIS fighters.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women and children make up the majority of the population at Al Hol detention camp in the Kurdish-led breakaway region of northeastern Syria.

item.title: The Slippery Science of Skeleton
item.description: Researchers are still figuring out how to enable athletes in the face-first Olympic sled race to go even faster.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:description: Matt Weston of Great Britain running at the start of a skeleton run at the Yanqing National Sliding Center in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: US Military Offers New Details on Raid That Led to Death of ISIS Leader
item.description: A tip from informants helped set in motion a commando raid that led to the death of the elusive terrorist, Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi, in Syria last week.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Ben Hubbard
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Anas Alkharboutli/picture alliance via Getty Images
item.media:description: The damaged house where Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi died during a raid by U.S. commandos in northwestern Syria last week.

item.title: Russia Massing More Troops Near Ukraine, Satellite Images Show
item.description: The Russian buildup includes more forces in Crimea, western Russia and Belarus, adding to fears that Russia could invade Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia’s Large-Scale Military Drills
item.description: Troops along the Ukraine border bring unease.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Russian Defense Ministry, via Agence France-Presse - Getty Images
item.media:description: Joint military exercises between Russia and Belarus in Brest, Belarus.

item.title: London Police Commissioner Announces Resignation
item.description: The commissioner, Cressida Dick, announced her resignation under pressure from the mayor over reports of bullying, misogyny and racism on the force.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Cressida Dick, the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, announced on Thursday that she would be stepping down as the leader of London’s Metropolitan Police.

item.title: Marie-Claire Chevalier, Catalyst for French Abortion Law, Dies at 66
item.description: While in high school in 1972, she was raped and became pregnant. Her illegal abortion paved the way for France to decriminalize the procedure in 1975.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Marie-Claire Chevalier, fourth from left, exited a French courthouse after she was acquitted of having an illegal abortion. With her are, from left, her lawyers Monique Antoine and Gisèle Halimi and her mother Michèle Chevalier.

item.title: France Announces a Big Buildup of Its Nuclear Power Program
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron outlined plans for a wave of new-generation atomic reactors as the country seeks to slash planet-warming emissions.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Jean-Francois Badias/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking at a turbine factory on Thursday. “The time has come for a nuclear renaissance,” he said.

item.title: Hear Lata Mangeshkar in These Four Streaming Films
item.description: Because Mangeshkar lent her voice to several generations of Bollywood stars, these movies double as a highlight reel for Hindi cinema.
item.dc:creator: Siddhant Adlakha
item.category: Lagaan: Once Upon a Time in India (Movie)

item.title: Paris Police Ban Protest Convoy Inspired by Ottawa Protests
item.description: The group takes its name, Convoi de la Liberté, from Canada’s Freedom Convoy, and like the Canadian protest, has brought together people espousing a wide range of motivations.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A woman flashes a victory sign from a car flying the Basque flag during the departure of the "Convoi de la Liberté," or “Freedom Convoy,” from southern France on Wednesday.

item.title: G.M. Cancels Shifts at Michigan Plant Over Canada Protest Disruption
item.description: Ford Motor and Toyota have also shut down some operations because factories could not get parts made in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing
item.media:description: Demonstrators blocking access to the Ambassador Bridge in Windsor, Ontario on Wednesday.

item.title: Boris Johnson Warns That Ukraine Crisis Is Reaching a Perilous Moment
item.description: Britain said it was readying 1,000 more troops to support NATO allies in case of a humanitarian crisis caused by Russian aggression against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, center, with Jens Stoltenberg, the NATO secretary general, right, on Thursday in Brussels.

item.title: Mitch McConnell vs. Republicans
item.description: Making sense of the G.O.P. leader’s squabble with his own party.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Mitch McConnell in the Capitol this week.

item.title: The Philippines Reopens to International Tourists
item.description: The Southeast Asian nation had closed its borders to most visitors for nearly two years.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:description: Passengers arriving at Manila’s international airport in the Philippines on Thursday.

item.title: European leaders say they seek peace, and warn Russia of retaliation for any aggression against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, center, listens to Polish President Andrzej Duda, left, during a joint press conference with French President Emmanuel Macron in Berlin on Tuesday.

item.title: Top British officials lead diplomatic efforts on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on Wednesday in Verkhnotoretske, in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A controversial diplomatic model.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at the front line in eastern Ukraine earlier this week.

item.title: As mask restrictions are set to lift in a handful of states, uncertainty lingers.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: A growing body of evidence, from lab experiments to real world studies, suggests that masking provides benefits in a variety of settings, including schools.

item.title: This Galápagos Volcano Produced a ‘Mesmerizing’ River of Fire
item.description: When Wolf Volcano erupted last month in a remote corner of Ecuador, its lava trail extended for miles in an orange line so bright that it was visible from space.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Court Orders Uganda to Pay $325 Million in Reparations to Congo
item.description: The International Court of Justice awarded the sum over Uganda’s role in conflicts in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: In a photo from 2003, forces from Uganda return through the town of Goli after withdrawing from the Democratic Republic of Congo’s embattled Ituri province.

item.title: Finns Don’t Wish ‘Finlandization’ on Ukraine (or Anyone)
item.description: The Cold War term for a kind of stifled sovereignty has gained attention as a possible solution to the standoff with Russia. But the nation it’s named for would rather forget about it.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Finland of today is a member of the European Union that uses the euro and deals with the United States and Europe on its own terms.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. Mask Mandates Lift
item.description: States loosened up rules as pandemic fatigue grew.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: A first-grade classroom in Chelsea, Mass., in September.

item.title: Boris Johnson Outlines Plan for Lifting Covid Restrictions in England
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who is fighting to save his job, said the easing of rules would come a month earlier than planned.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Holly-Marie Cato for The New York Times
item.media:description: Commuters in London last month. Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Wednesday announced plans to end Britain’s remaining domestic coronavirus restrictions.

item.title: In Ukraine Crisis, Putin Faces a Stark Choice
item.description: Russia can seize control over Ukraine or keep strong economic ties to Europe. It will be hard to do both.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at the front line in eastern Ukraine on Tuesday.

item.title: Germany Has a New Climate Envoy: an American Greenpeace Activist
item.description: Jennifer Morgan, the American head of Greenpeace, has lived in Germany since 2003 and has applied for German citizenship.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Jennifer Morgan, left, will join Germany’s foreign ministry as a climate policy envoy, Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock announced on Wednesday in Berlin.

item.title: France Protest Convoy Begins, Inspired by Canada's Truckers
item.description: Dozens of drivers are heading for the French capital to oppose the government’s vaccine rules, a direct echo of the “Freedom Convoy” protests in Ottawa.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Members of a convoy protesting France’s Covid-19 restrictions preparing to depart from Nice on their way to Paris, on Wednesday.

item.title: State by State, Germany Relaxes Covid Rules, Even as Cases Surge
item.description: Though case numbers are at a record level, Germany is recording relatively few Covid deaths and stable hospitalization rates.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: A department store in Berlin last year. Several German states are loosening Covid restrictions even as the country’s caseload rises.

item.title: China and Russia's 'Alliance of Autocracies'
item.description: China and Russia have formed an “alliance of autocracies.”
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping in Beijing last week.

item.title: Tonga Extends Its Lockdown as Covid Cases Rise
item.description: The island nation barely saw the coronavirus in the first two years of the pandemic. But after a volcanic eruption, an outbreak among visiting aid workers has pushed up its caseload.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Cpl Robert Whitmore/Australian Defence Force, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Aid workers from Australia assessed damage last week in Tonga, which was hit by a volcanic eruption and tsunami last month.

item.title: Covid Cases Spike in Asia After Lunar New Year Celebrations
item.description: A spike in cases across Asia has followed this month’s holiday.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A medical worker giving instructions for coronavirus tests in Seoul on Tuesday.

item.title: New York is dropping its indoor mask mandate, joining other blue states in easing Covid rules.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer, Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul is set to join other Democratic governors in lifting some of New York’s Covid mandates.

item.title: How the ‘Garlic Girls’ Overcame Abuse to Return to the Olympics
item.description: The South Korean curling team helped revive a painful discussion about the mistreatment of athletes in their country, leading the way for others to come forward.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: South Korea’s women’s curling team — Kim Eun-jung, Kim Kyeong-ae, Kim Seon-yeong, Kim Yeong-mi and Kim Cho-hi — with their silver medals during the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang.

item.title: Photographer’s Death Casts Harsh Light on the Cold Streets of Paris
item.description: René Robert, known for his pictures of flamenco, died of hypothermia after falling on a busy road, seemingly unassisted. The death shocked many, but echoed the indifference homeless people face every day.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Stern warnings from Europe to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Andrzej Duda of Poland, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, and President Emmanuel Macron of France in Berlin on Tuesday.

item.title: Vaccine Policy in Los Angeles County Aims to Pressure Sheriff
item.description: The move will apply pressure to the sheriff’s department, which has a vaccination rate of 54 percent.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:credit: Allison Zaucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: People registering to get vaccinated at a Los Angeles County’s vaccination site in Los Angeles, California, last month.

item.title: Europe Calls for Peace, but Not at Any Price
item.description: Two days of intense diplomacy on both sides of the Atlantic leave the standoff over Ukraine with Russia frozen in place.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Andrzej Duda of Poland, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, and President Emmanuel Macron of France in Berlin on Tuesday.

item.title: With No End in Sight, Ottawa Protests Extend Beyond Canada’s Borders
item.description: Officials are grappling with a new protest blocking a major border crossing, while similar demonstrations have disrupted traffic in New Zealand and Australia.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Ian Austen and Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Demonstrators in front of Parliament Hill as truckers and their supporters continued to protest against vaccine mandates on Tuesday in Ottawa.

item.title: Greta Ferusic Dies at 97; Survived Auschwitz and Siege of Sarajevo
item.description: She was the only one in her family to survive the Holocaust, then endured the shelling of her city during the Bosnian war. A documentary chronicled her story.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Greta Ferusic in 2000. A 1997 film, “Greta,” chronicled her experience of the Holocaust and then the siege of Sarajevo.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Undercuts Macron
item.description: The Kremlin rejected reports of commitments.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, right, with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Tuesday.

item.title: Denmark is overflowing with virus cases, but the population is partying.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emilia Silberg, 19, dancing in Copenhagen on Saturday, when Denmark’s nightclubs reopened.
